UploadedFile.title: UploadedFile
UploadedFile.description: Represents a file or text content generated and saved by a user. This can include images, PDFs, Word documents, PowerPoint presentations, and text documents, as well as transcribed and summarized text.

id.description: Unique identifier for the uploaded file or content.

fileName.description: The name of the file or content.

fileType.description: The MIME type of the file (e.g., 'image/jpeg', 'application/pdf', 'text/plain').

fileSize.description: The size of the file in bytes (if applicable).

uploadDate.description: The date and time when the file was uploaded or content was created.

userId.description: Reference to User. (Relationship: User 1:N UploadedFile). The user who created or uploaded the content.

storageLocation.description: The location where the file is stored (e.g., cloud storage URL). Not applicable for text content stored directly in Firestore.

transcribedText.description: The full text content, e.g., from speech-to-text.

summarizedText.description: The summarized version of the text content.

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the Medo.Ai Time Hub application.

email.description: The email address of the user.

registrationDate.description: The date and time when the user registered.

lastLogin.description: The date and time of the user's last login.

definition.description: Stores user profile information. Path-based ownership ensures only the user can modify their own profile.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user.

definition.description: Stores files and text content created by each user. Includes denormalized 'userId' for authorization independence.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user who created the content.

params.name: fileId
params.description: The unique identifier for the content.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to provide a secure and scalable solution for the Medo.Ai Time Hub application, focusing on efficient file storage and retrieval, and user management. The design adheres to the core principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC, and QAPs. It leverages Structural Segregation to ensure each collection has a homogeneous security posture and Access Modeling for consistent authorization patterns.

Authorization Independence is achieved by denormalizing the `userId` into the `uploadedFiles` collection. This eliminates the need for `get()` calls to the `/users/{userId}` document to verify ownership, allowing for atomic operations and simplified security rules.

The design supports QAPs by segregating user-specific files under the `/users/{userId}/uploadedFiles/{fileId}` path. This ensures that listing files is restricted to authorized users only, as security rules can easily enforce that only the user with the matching `userId` can access these files. This also provides a clear ownership model, making security rules simple and robust.
